articles.headline: Analysis: Ambitions AreFueling Union Split
articles.snippet: News analysis of huge split in organized labor as fueled by workers' stagnant living standards, ascendancy of service sector and labor's lack of success in politics and unionizing, but also by conflicting ambitions of AFL-CIO president John J Swee...
articles.abstract: News analysis of huge split in organized labor as fueled by workers' stagnant living standards, ascendancy of service sector and labor's lack of success in politics and unionizing, but also by conflicting ambitions of AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney and his onetime protege, Andrew L Stern of Service Employees International Union; photo; schism is sealed as Stern and Teamsters leader James P Hoffa pull out as AFL-CIO marks 50th anniversary; Stern, known for eloquence, drive and impatience, has long pushed for move; United Food and Commercial Workers and Unite Here boycott convention and may pull out as well; Sweeney has tried to work by consensus, saying AFL-CIO rules prevent him from punishing unions that do not do organizing; Stern seeks far more aggressive recruitment efforts using much more money; Stern seen emboldened by his union's success in organizing growing service sector; his critics charge power grab (M)

articles.headline: Palestinian SecurityForces Are Found Unfit
articles.snippet: Independent survey finds Palestinian Authority security forces are divided, weak, overstaffed, badly motivated and underarmed, legacy of Yasir Arafat era; says more attention must be paid to building up institutions rather than personalities; surv...
articles.abstract: Independent survey finds Palestinian Authority security forces are divided, weak, overstaffed, badly motivated and underarmed, legacy of Yasir Arafat era; says more attention must be paid to building up institutions rather than personalities; survey, coordinated with Lt Gen William E Ward, aims to analyze deficiencies, suggest long-term improvements to help guide foreign donors and Palestinians and map cooperation with Israel on Gaza pullout; report warns of risks from Islamic Jihad or other attacks, Israeli settler incursions and unclear Israeli army plans; study is by Strategic Assessments Initiative, funded by Netherlands and Canada as part of Ward's international mandate; group official Jarad Chopra explains; report says problems stem from Arafat's policy of duplication and promoting rivalries (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, July 25 - The security forces of the Palestinian Authority are divided, weak, overstaffed, badly motivated and underarmed, and more attention must be paid to building up institutions rather than personalities, says the first independent survey of the complicated Palestinian security environment since the death of Yasir Arafat.

articles.headline: 2 Connected to Reinsurer May Face U.S. Action
articles.snippet: RenaissanceRe Holdings, Bermuda-based reinsurer that recently restated three years of earnings, discloses that SEC has advised its chief executive, James N Stanard, that he may soon face civil complaint; also says regulators have recommended filin...
articles.abstract: RenaissanceRe Holdings, Bermuda-based reinsurer that recently restated three years of earnings, discloses that SEC has advised its chief executive, James N Stanard, that he may soon face civil complaint; also says regulators have recommended filing of enforcement proceedings against Michael W Cash, senior vice president in RenaissanceRe's specialty reinsurance unit, who resigned on July 11; Cash left company after refusing to accept subpoena from SEC seeking his testimony about company's restatement (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign that the regulatory scrutiny of the insurance industry is not abating, RenaissanceRe Holdings, a Bermuda-based reinsurer that recently restated three years of earnings, disclosed yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission has advised its chief executive, James N. Stanard, that he may soon face a civil complaint.

articles.headline: New U.S. Envoy Will Press Iraqis on Their Charter
articles.snippet: New US ambassador to Iraq, Afghan-American Zalmay Khalilzad, signals that US will work to guarantee women's rights under new constitution and moderate push by ethnic and sectarian groups for broad autonomy; speaks twice of need to avert civil war,...
articles.abstract: New US ambassador to Iraq, Afghan-American Zalmay Khalilzad, signals that US will work to guarantee women's rights under new constitution and moderate push by ethnic and sectarian groups for broad autonomy; speaks twice of need to avert civil war, possibility that US and Iraqi officials discuss with increasing frequency, warning groups they have to accept less than maximum aspirations; public remarks, after Amb John D Negroponte's low profile, reflect urgency as US pushes Iraqi to finish constitution, which Khalilzad says must enshrine equality; message seen to Shiite majority and Kurdish minority, both pushing for self-rule; insurgents continue to ravage Baghdad area; suicide bombers kill at least six people at Sadeer Hotel and others elsewhere; photo of hospital emergency room that doctors say was ransacked by police (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 25 - The new American ambassador to Iraq waded into the debate over its constitution on Monday, signaling that the United States would work to guarantee the rights of Iraqi women and to blunt the desires of ethnic and religious factions pushing for broader autonomy in the new Iraqi state.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and James Glanz

articles.headline: Disney Selects New Chief of Miramax
articles.snippet: Walt Disney Co chooses Daniel Battsek, who has overseen company's film distribution in Britain, to run Miramax Films after departure of its co-chairmen, Harvey and Bob Weinstein; Battsek faces challenge of re-establishing Miramax label as a force ...
articles.abstract: Walt Disney Co chooses Daniel Battsek, who has overseen company's film distribution in Britain, to run Miramax Films after departure of its co-chairmen, Harvey and Bob Weinstein; Battsek faces challenge of re-establishing Miramax label as a force for independent or specialty films; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 25 - The Walt Disney Company on Monday chose Daniel Battsek, who has overseen the company's film distribution in Britain, to run Miramax Films after the departure of its co-chairmen, Harvey and Bob Weinstein.

articles.headline: Some Documents of Supreme Court Choice Will Be Released
articles.snippet: Bush administration will release documents from Judge John G Roberts' tenure as assistant counsel in Reagan White House and from his earlier work for attorney general, but not papers from his four years as deputy solicitor general under first Pres...
articles.abstract: Bush administration will release documents from Judge John G Roberts' tenure as assistant counsel in Reagan White House and from his earlier work for attorney general, but not papers from his four years as deputy solicitor general under first Pres Bush, starting in 1989; decision fulfills Sen Arlen Spector's request for Judiciary Committee, but not requests of Democrats who say files could shed light on Supreme Court nominee's thinking on key issues; White House will work with National Archives and Reagan library to speed processing and waive privilege claims; officials say that, by contrast, Roberts' papers as Kenneth Starr's deputy cover sensitive conversations developing legal arguments for Supreme Court cases; Democratic Sen Patrick Leahy says attorney-client privilege does not apply in either case; photo of Roberts at Capitol (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 25 - The Bush administration plans to release documents from Judge John G. Roberts's tenure in the White House counsel's office in the mid-1980's and his earlier job working for the attorney general, but will not make public papers covering the four years he spent as principal deputy solicitor general starting in 1989, two senior administration officials said Monday.
articles.byline: This article is by Richard W. Stevenson, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Main Street in the Cross Hairs
articles.snippet: Data thieves obtain cardholder information of tens of thousands of customers at retail merchants, singling out stores with strong wireless signals and weakly protected data; could have parked car outside store or set up in local Starbucks, using l...
articles.abstract: Data thieves obtain cardholder information of tens of thousands of customers at retail merchants, singling out stores with strong wireless signals and weakly protected data; could have parked car outside store or set up in local Starbucks, using laptop computer outfitted with off-the-shelf wireless receiver; may even have received help from Web sites listing geographic coordinates of easy-to-target stores; from there, it would be easy to pick up signals being broadcast around the store and use them to gain access to its computer systems; unlike banks and other financial institution, merchants often lack technological expertise and management attention to keep their customers' information secure; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Along a crowded stretch of highway just south of Miami's downtown is a shopping area that might be called the data theft capital of the United States. In the wireless hacker equivalent of a drive-by shooting wave, criminals obtained the cardholder information of tens of thousands of customers at four major stores there, including a DSW Shoes retail outlet that appears to have been the initial source of a chainwide data breach.

articles.headline: Home Sales Still Rising to Records
articles.snippet: National Assn of Realtors reports that nation's roaring housing market sets its second record in three months as sales of existing homes climbed 2.7 percent in June, to 7.33 million; low mortgage rates and strong demand drive frenetic sales activi...
articles.abstract: National Assn of Realtors reports that nation's roaring housing market sets its second record in three months as sales of existing homes climbed 2.7 percent in June, to 7.33 million; low mortgage rates and strong demand drive frenetic sales activity; median price rises at nearly its highest annual pace in almost 25 years, 14.7 percent, to record $219,000; average sales price climbs 9.4 percent, to $268,000 (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation's roaring housing market set its second record in three months as sales of existing homes climbed 2.7 percent in June, to 7.33 million, according to a report released yesterday.

articles.headline: A Different Beat: Toyota Raises Prices While Detroit Cuts Deeply
articles.snippet: Toyota Motor announces slight price increase on many models sold in United States, at time when Detroit's Big Three automakers are offering steeply reduced 'employee discounts' to nearly everyone who walks in door; says increases are necessary bec...
articles.abstract: Toyota Motor announces slight price increase on many models sold in United States, at time when Detroit's Big Three automakers are offering steeply reduced 'employee discounts' to nearly everyone who walks in door; says increases are necessary because of rising costs of steel and other raw materials; move also reflects determination of Toyota and other major Japanese car companies to avoid competing on price; photo (M)

articles.headline: Radio Payoffs Are Described as Sony Settles
articles.snippet: SONY BMG, in $10-million settlement with New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer, admits giving gifts to curry favor with radio station programmers to get them to play specific songs; Spitzer inquiry into 'pervasive' payola, term from 1950's radio scandal...
articles.abstract: SONY BMG, in $10-million settlement with New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer, admits giving gifts to curry favor with radio station programmers to get them to play specific songs; Spitzer inquiry into 'pervasive' payola, term from 1950's radio scandals, now shifts to Vivendi Universal, Warner Music Group and EMI Group and to radio companies whose employees have accepted gifts; SONY admits wrongdoing, dismisses top promotion executive at Epic label and reportedly disciplines four Sony Urban and Epic executives; probe finds company provided entertainers for station-sponsored concerts, paid station bills, gave vacations and other gifts and used interns and vendors to call in requests; photos of Spitzer and of e-mails documenting practices (M)
articles.byline: By Jeff Leeds and Louise Story
